The lawsuit alleges that on and after January 20, 2025, OPM granted DOGE agents sweeping, "administrative" access to its computer systems, which contain highly sensitive personal, financial, and employment records for millions of federal employees. The plaintiffs claimed this access was granted without the proper security vetting or clearances required by law and OPM's own protocols. The suit sought declaratory and injunctive relief, asserting that the defendants' actions violated the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).

The plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order on February 14, 2025. In response, on March 14, the government defendants moved to dismiss the case, arguing that the plaintiffs lacked legal standing because they had not suffered a concrete injury and that their claims were not legally viable.

On April 3, 2025, Judge Denise L. Cote issued an opinion and order (2025 WL 996542) that largely denied the motion to dismiss. The court ruled that the plaintiffs had established standing, finding that the unauthorized access to their private information constituted a concrete injury analogous to the common law tort of intrusion upon seclusion. The court allowed the APA claims to proceed, reasoning that OPM's actions constituted "final agency action" and that the Privacy Act did not provide an adequate alternative remedy for the injunctive relief sought. The direct claims for injunctive relief under the Privacy Act itself were dismissed, though the underlying violations could serve as the basis for the APA claims.

Following this decision, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction on April 25, 2025. After an evidentiary hearing, Judge Cote granted the motion on June 9, 2025. The court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claims that OPM had violated the Privacy Act by disclosing records to individuals who either were not OPM employees or lacked a legitimate "need to know," and by failing to establish appropriate security safeguards. A formal preliminary injunction was issued on June 20, 2025, which requires OPM to report on the procedures it has implemented to ensure future compliance with the Privacy Act. The order was administratively stayed for 14 days and became effective after the plaintiffs posted a $1,000 bond. The case is noted to be related to similar lawsuits challenging DOGE activities at other federal agencies.
results.46095:
On February 10, 2025, several associations of universities, numerous individual universities, and other research institutions, represented by private counsel, filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) and the National Institutes of Health (NIH). The case was consolidated for proceedings with two similar lawsuits, one filed by 22 states and another by a group of medical associations.

The lawsuit challenged guidance issued by NIH on Friday, February 7, 2025, which was set to take effect the following Monday. This guidance unilaterally imposed a 15% cap on the reimbursement of "indirect costs" for all new and existing NIH research grants awarded to institutions of higher education. Indirect costs, which cover essential research support like facility maintenance, utilities, and administration, had for decades been reimbursed based on rates individually negotiated with each institution. The plaintiffs argued that this sudden change, made without notice, would devastate medical research, force layoffs, halt critical clinical trials, and upend significant financial commitments made in reliance on the established system.

The plaintiffs' cause of action was under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). They alleged the NIH guidance was unlawful because it violated Section 224 of the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2024—a legislative rider Congress enacted in 2018 and renewed annually specifically to prevent NIH from modifying the negotiated rate system. The plaintiffs further claimed the guidance was arbitrary and capricious, violated HHS's own regulations, was procedurally invalid for lacking a notice-and-comment period, and was impermissibly retroactive in its application to existing grants. They sought a declaratory judgment, vacatur of the guidance, and injunctive relief to prevent its implementation.

The case was assigned to Judge Angel Kelley of the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Following the filing of a motion for a temporary restraining order, the court issued a nationwide temporary restraining order to maintain the status quo. After briefing and a hearing, Judge Kelley granted a nationwide preliminary injunction on March 5, 2025. The court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claims that the guidance violated the congressional appropriations rider and existing HHS regulations. The court also determined the action was arbitrary and capricious for failing to provide adequate reasoning and for ignoring the institutions' significant reliance interests, and that it was procedurally improper and impermissibly retroactive.

On April 4, 2025, upon an assented-to motion by the parties to expedite an appeal, the court converted the preliminary injunction into a final judgment and permanent injunction. The final decree permanently enjoined the federal government from implementing the guidance nationwide and formally vacated the guidance in its entirety. The government filed a notice of appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit on April 8, 2025.
results.46023:
On February 3, 2025, three large membership organizations—an advocate for retired Americans and two labor unions representing government and service employees—filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Secretary of the Treasury, the Department of the Treasury, and its Bureau of the Fiscal Service. The plaintiffs, represented by Public Citizen Litigation Group and the State Democracy Defenders Fund, allege that the Treasury Department unlawfully granted individuals affiliated with a new initiative, the "Department of Government Efficiency" (DOGE), access to the Bureau of the Fiscal Service's payment systems. These systems contain sensitive personal and financial data, including Social Security numbers, bank account details, and tax information, for millions of Americans.

The complaint, filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia and assigned to Judge Colleen Kollar-Kotelly, seeks declaratory and injunctive relief under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). The plaintiffs contend that granting DOGE affiliates access to this data is arbitrary and capricious, contrary to law, and exceeds the agency's statutory authority by violating the Privacy Act of 1974 and the Internal Revenue Code (26 U.S.C. § 6103).

The plaintiffs immediately moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO). Following a hearing, the parties agreed to a consent order, entered by the court on February 6, 2025, which deferred a ruling on the TRO. The order prohibited the defendants from providing access to their payment systems, with an exception for two named individuals designated as Special Government Employees who were granted "read only" access for their official duties. The order was later modified on February 20, 2025, to substitute a new employee for one who had resigned.

The court converted the TRO motion into a motion for a preliminary injunction. On March 7, 2025, Judge Kollar-Kotelly issued a memorandum opinion denying the preliminary injunction (*All. for Retired Ams. v. Bessent*, 2025 WL 740401 (D.D.C. Mar. 7, 2025)). The court found that while the plaintiffs had established Article III standing, they failed to demonstrate a likelihood of suffering irreparable harm under the D.C. Circuit's high standard, which requires a showing that the harm is "both certain and great." The denial of the injunction also dissolved the interim consent order.

Following the ruling, the court ordered the defendants to produce the administrative record. After the plaintiffs objected to its contents, the court granted a subsequent motion for limited, expedited discovery, finding the record was insufficient to "ascertain the contours of the precise policy at issue." The defendants have since filed a motion to dismiss or, in the alternative, for summary judgment, and the plaintiffs have filed a cross-motion for summary judgment. The case is ongoing, with these dispositive motions pending before the court. The proceedings have referenced several related cases challenging the DOGE initiative's access to records at other federal agencies.
results.46563:
On May 2, 2025, a coalition of eight U.S. cities and counties filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Departments of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) and Transportation (DOT), the Federal Transit Administration (FTA), and their respective secretaries. The plaintiffs, represented by a combination of private law firms, public interest organizations, and their own government counsel, challenged new conditions the agencies began imposing on federal grant agreements. The lawsuit has since expanded significantly, with two amended complaints adding over twenty more local government entities and public agencies as plaintiffs, and including the Federal Highway Administration (FHWA), Federal Aviation Administration (FAA), Federal Railroad Administration (FRA), and the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) as defendants.

The lawsuit's factual basis is that following a series of executive orders, the federal agencies unilaterally inserted new, unauthorized conditions into agreements for congressionally-appropriated funds. These funds, totaling over $4 billion, support critical local services, including HUD's Continuum of Care (CoC) grants for homelessness assistance and various DOT and HHS grants for transportation and public health. The challenged conditions require grant recipients to certify they do not operate programs promoting Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI); agree to cooperate with federal immigration enforcement; use specific systems to verify the immigration status of beneficiaries; and not use funds to "promote" what the administration defines as "gender ideology" or "elective abortion."

The plaintiffs seek declaratory and injunctive relief, arguing that the conditions are unlawful. Their causes of action are rooted in the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) and the U.S. Constitution, alleging that the agencies' actions violate the separation of powers, the Spending Clause, the Tenth Amendment's anti-commandeering principle, and the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause (void-for-vagueness doctrine).

The case is before Judge Barbara J. Rothstein in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. After the initial filing, the plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO), which Judge Rothstein granted on May 7, 2025. As new plaintiffs joined the case, the court granted a second TRO on May 23, 2025.

On June 3, 2025, Judge Rothstein granted a preliminary injunction covering all plaintiffs and claims in the First Amended Complaint. The court rejected the federal government's argument that the district court lacked jurisdiction under the Tucker Act, finding the case was based on constitutional and statutory rights, not contract law, and sought equitable relief rather than monetary damages. The court found the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits, reasoning that the agencies exceeded their statutory authority and violated the separation of powers by imposing conditions not authorized by Congress. The judge also found the actions were likely arbitrary and capricious under the APA. A third preliminary injunction was granted on August 12, 2025, extending this relief to the additional plaintiffs and claims included in the Second Amended Complaint.

The preliminary injunctions, which remain in effect pending further court orders, prohibit the defendant agencies from imposing or enforcing the challenged grant conditions and from withholding funds from the plaintiffs for refusing to accept them. The federal government filed a notice of appeal of the June 3 preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on June 9, 2025.
results.46484:
On April 23, 2025, the American Bar Association (ABA), represented by counsel from the Democracy Forward Foundation, filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) and two of its senior officials, the Attorney General and Deputy Attorney General. The suit alleged that the DOJ unlawfully retaliated against the ABA for exercising its First Amendment rights.

The complaint states that for decades, the ABA’s Commission on Domestic & Sexual Violence had received federal grants from the DOJ’s Office on Violence Against Women (OVW) to fund trainings and provide technical assistance for legal professionals working with survivors of domestic and sexual violence. In early 2025, the ABA issued public statements critical of the administration and joined a lawsuit challenging the administration’s actions on an unrelated matter. On April 9, 2025, the Deputy Attorney General issued a memorandum to all DOJ employees restricting their engagement with the ABA, citing the ABA’s lawsuit and its support for “activist causes.” The following day, the DOJ terminated all five of the ABA’s active OVW grants, totaling $3.2 million, stating only that the grants no longer effectuated “agency priorities.”

The ABA’s lawsuit sought declaratory and injunctive relief, asserting that the grant terminations violated the First and Fifth Amendments of the U.S. Constitution and the Administrative Procedure Act. The primary claim was that the DOJ’s action constituted unlawful retaliation for the ABA’s protected speech and its right to petition the government through litigation.

The case was assigned to Judge Christopher R. Cooper of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The day after filing the complaint, the ABA moved for a temporary restraining order and a preliminary injunction to bar the DOJ from enforcing the grant terminations. On May 14, 2025, Judge Cooper granted the motion for a preliminary injunction. In the accompanying memorandum opinion, the court found that the ABA was likely to succeed on the merits of its First Amendment retaliation claim. The court rejected the government’s argument that the case belonged in the Court of Federal Claims, ruling that the claim was based on the Constitution, not contract law. The opinion noted the strong causal link between the ABA’s protected speech, the Deputy Attorney General’s critical memorandum, and the immediate termination of the grants the next day. The court ordered the DOJ to cease enforcing the termination and to continue disbursing funds under the existing grant agreements.

Following the injunction, the parties entered discussions to resolve the matter. On July 17, 2025, the court struck the DOJ’s motion to dismiss as moot and administratively closed the case, pending periodic joint status reports from the parties.
results.46279:
On March 23, 2025, four noncitizens with final removal orders filed a class-action lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Homeland Security (DHS), the Attorney General, and other officials. Represented by legal services organizations, the plaintiffs challenged a government policy of deporting or seeking to deport noncitizens to a "third country"—a country not designated in their original removal proceedings—without providing advance written notice or a meaningful opportunity to present claims that they would face persecution or torture there. The plaintiffs alleged this policy violates the Immigration and Nationality Act (INA), the Foreign Affairs Reform and Restructuring Act (FARRA), the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Due Process Clause of the Fifth Amendment. They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to halt the practice.

The case was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts and assigned to Judge Brian E. Murphy. The plaintiffs immediately sought a temporary restraining order (TRO), citing a February 18, 2025, DHS directive that instructed officers to review cases for third-country removal and re-detention, placing numerous noncitizens at imminent risk. One named plaintiff, O.C.G., had already been granted protection from removal to his native Guatemala but was then removed without notice to Mexico, where he had previously been assaulted, and was ultimately returned to Guatemala.

On March 28, 2025, Judge Murphy granted a TRO, finding the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their due process claims. The order enjoined the government from removing class members to a third country without first providing written notice and a meaningful opportunity to apply for protection under the Convention Against Torture (CAT). The government's appeal of the TRO was denied a stay by the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit.

Following a hearing, on April 18, 2025, the district court certified a class of all individuals with final removal orders whom DHS has deported or will deport to a non-designated third country on or after February 18, 2025. The court also issued a preliminary injunction requiring that before any such removal, the government must provide written notice to the individual and their counsel in a language they understand, and a meaningful opportunity to seek CAT protection. The injunction specified that if a "reasonable fear" is found, the government must move to reopen immigration proceedings; if not, the individual must be given 15 days to file their own motion to reopen.

Disputes over compliance arose quickly. After the government attempted to remove class members to South Sudan on May 20, 2025, with less than 24 hours' notice, the court found the government in violation of the preliminary injunction. On May 21, 2025, the court clarified that a "meaningful opportunity" requires a minimum of 10 days' notice before removal. As a remedy for the violation, the court ordered that the affected class members, who were being held at a U.S. military base in Djibouti, be given a reasonable fear interview with access to counsel, either abroad or upon return to the U.S.

In a key development, the government filed a notice on May 16, 2025, retracting its earlier sworn declaration that plaintiff O.C.G. had been asked about and denied any fear of removal to Mexico. Based on this retraction, on May 23, 2025, Judge Murphy ordered the government to facilitate O.C.G.’s immediate return to the United States.

The government appealed the preliminary injunction and, after the First Circuit denied a stay, sought relief from the U.S. Supreme Court. The Supreme Court granted a stay of the preliminary injunction pending the outcome of the appeal. The case remains active in the district court, where the parties have filed motions for summary judgment and to stay proceedings pending the appeal.
results.46186:
On February 28, 2025, a coalition of noncitizens, their U.S.-based sponsors, and the Haitian Bridge Alliance filed a class-action lawsuit against the President of the United States and senior officials at the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and its component agencies. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel and non-profit legal organizations, challenge the Trump administration's actions to terminate various humanitarian parole programs and suspend the processing of immigration applications for those already granted parole.

The lawsuit was prompted by a series of executive orders and agency memoranda issued on and after Inauguration Day, January 20, 2025. These directives terminated several "categorical" parole programs, including Uniting for Ukraine (U4U), the processes for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans (CHNV), Operation Allies Welcome (OAW) for Afghans, Family Reunification Parole (FRP), Military Parole-in-Place (MPIP), and the Central American Minors (CAM) program. The administration's stated legal basis was that these programs were "blatantly inconsistent" with the Immigration and Nationality Act's requirement for "case-by-case" parole grants. Concurrently, DHS suspended the adjudication of all other immigration benefit applications—such as for asylum, Temporary Protected Status (TPS), and green cards—for individuals already in the U.S. through these programs, citing a need to review vetting standards.

The plaintiffs allege these actions violate the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) as they are contrary to law, arbitrary and capricious, and in excess of statutory authority. They also bring a claim under the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause. The suit seeks declaratory judgments that the parole programs are lawful and the administration's actions are illegal, as well as injunctive relief to resume the processing of parole and other immigration benefit applications.

The case is before Judge Indira Talwani of the U.S. District Court for the District of Massachusetts. Key proceedings and rulings include:

*   **CHNV Parole Termination:** On March 25, 2025, DHS published a Federal Register Notice officially terminating the CHNV programs and announcing that all existing two-year grants of CHNV parole would be truncated, ending on April 24, 2025. In response to an emergency motion from the plaintiffs, Judge Talwani issued a preliminary injunction on April 14, 2025, staying the mass termination of existing CHNV parole grants and work authorizations. On the same day, the court certified a class of all CHNV parolees affected by the termination.
*   **Appeal and Supreme Court Stay:** The government appealed the April 14 injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit, which denied a stay pending appeal on May 5, 2025. The government then sought emergency relief from the U.S. Supreme Court, which granted a stay on May 30, 2025. The Supreme Court's order allows the government to terminate the existing CHNV parole grants while the appeal proceeds in the First Circuit.
*   **Suspension of Benefits Adjudication:** On May 28, 2025, Judge Talwani granted a separate preliminary injunction staying the government's suspension of adjudications for other immigration benefits. This order requires DHS to resume processing applications for re-parole (for programs like U4U and OAW), initial parole under the MPIP program, and other benefits like asylum and TPS for all parolee class members. The court also amended its class certification order to include subclasses for these affected individuals.
*   **Ongoing Proceedings:** The government has filed a motion to dismiss the complaint, and the plaintiffs have filed a motion for partial summary judgment regarding the termination of CHNV parole. The court has issued several orders directing DHS to report on its compliance with the May 28 injunction amidst plaintiffs' allegations that processing holds have continued. The government has also appealed the May 28 injunction and class certification order.
results.46180:
On February 25, 2025, several national and state-level professional organizations for educators and sociologists filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Education and its senior officials in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel from the Democracy Forward Foundation, were later joined by a public school district from Oregon.

The case centered on a "Dear Colleague Letter" issued by the Department of Education's Office for Civil Rights on February 14, 2025. The letter announced a new interpretation of Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 following the Supreme Court's decision in *Students for Fair Admissions, Inc. v. President and Fellows of Harvard College*. The plaintiffs alleged that the letter unlawfully misrepresented existing law to prohibit or chill a wide range of educational activities, including teaching about "systemic and structural racism," offering Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI) programs, and supporting student affinity groups.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, arguing that the letter was an unlawful agency action under the Administrative Procedure Act (APA) because it was arbitrary and capricious, exceeded statutory authority, and was a legislative rule promulgated without the required notice-and-comment period. They also alleged the letter violated the First Amendment's guarantees of free speech and association and the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause due to its vagueness.

After the initial filing, the case was assigned to Judge Stephanie A. Gallagher. The court questioned whether Maryland was the most appropriate venue but ultimately found it was proper. The scope of the litigation expanded when, on April 3, 2025, the Department of Education demanded that state and local education agencies certify their compliance with the legal interpretation embodied in the letter (the "Certification Requirement"). The plaintiffs filed a motion for preliminary injunction to block the letter and a second motion to block the certification.

On April 24, 2025, Judge Gallagher issued a memorandum opinion and an order staying the February 14 Dear Colleague Letter under APA § 705. The court found the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their APA claim, concluding the letter was likely a legislative rule that had improperly bypassed notice-and-comment procedures, was arbitrary and capricious, exceeded the Department's statutory authority, and was contrary to the First Amendment. The court denied the motion to enjoin the Certification Requirement at that time because it had not yet been challenged in the operative complaint.

Following the ruling, the plaintiffs filed a Second Amended Complaint to add claims specifically challenging the Certification Requirement on the same APA and constitutional grounds. The parties then filed cross-motions for summary judgment.

On August 14, 2025, Judge Gallagher issued a final judgment in favor of the plaintiffs on most of their claims. In her memorandum opinion, she held that both the Dear Colleague Letter and the Certification Requirement were unlawful legislative rules that violated the APA's procedural requirements. She further found the actions were arbitrary and capricious, exceeded the Department's statutory authority, and violated the First and Fifth Amendments. The court's final order vacated both the February 14, 2025 Dear Colleague Letter and the April 3, 2025 Certification Requirement.
results.46119:
On February 13, 2025, a group of 26 current and former employees and contractors of the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID) filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland. The suit was brought against a senior presidential advisor, the United States DOGE Service, and the Department of Government Efficiency (collectively “DOGE”), an entity created by Executive Order to improve government efficiency. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel and a non-profit advocacy group, alleged that the advisor, acting as the de facto head of DOGE without having been appointed as a principal officer with the advice and consent of the Senate, had begun to unconstitutionally dismantle USAID.

The lawsuit alleges that the advisor and his DOGE team took control of USAID’s digital infrastructure, shut down its headquarters and website, placed a majority of its workforce on administrative leave, and began terminating contracts and grants. The plaintiffs claimed these actions caused them financial, professional, and reputational harm, and created anxiety over the security of their sensitive personal data which had been accessed by DOGE personnel. The complaint sought declaratory and injunctive relief, asserting violations of the U.S. Constitution’s Appointments Clause and the separation of powers doctrine.

On February 18, 2025, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. After a hearing, Judge Theodore D. Chuang granted the motion in part on March 18, 2025. In his opinion (*J. Does 1-26 v. Musk*, 2025 WL 840574 (D. Md. Mar. 18, 2025)), Judge Chuang found the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claims, concluding that the advisor was exercising the authority of a principal officer without a proper appointment and that the executive branch's actions to effectively eliminate a congressionally established agency likely violated separation of powers. The injunction prohibited the defendants from taking further action to shut down USAID and required the reinstatement of employees’ access to agency systems.

The government immediately appealed the preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, which granted a stay of the injunction on March 28, 2025, pending the appeal's resolution.

While the appeal was pending, the plaintiffs filed a Second Amended Complaint on May 30, 2025, which reframed the case as a proposed class action and added new defendants, including USAID itself, the U.S. Department of State, the President, the Secretary of State, and other high-level officials. On August 13, 2025, Judge Chuang granted in part and denied in part the defendants' motion to dismiss, allowing the core constitutional claims against the presidential advisor, DOGE, USAID, and certain officials in their official capacities to proceed. On August 18, 2025, the court certified a class of all persons employed by USAID since January 20, 2025, for the purposes of seeking injunctive and declaratory relief. Following these rulings, the Fourth Circuit granted the government's motion to hold the appeal in abeyance pending further proceedings in the district court.
results.46099:
On February 10, 2025, two non-profit organizations, later joined by a third, filed a lawsuit against the President of the United States, the U.S. Department of State, the U.S. Agency for International Development (USAID), the Office of Management and Budget (OMB), and the heads of those agencies. The plaintiffs, represented by public interest counsel from Public Citizen Litigation Group, challenged the administration’s suspension of foreign assistance funding. The case was consolidated with a related case, *Global Health Council v. Trump*, and assigned to Judge Amir H. Ali of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia.

The lawsuit was precipitated by Executive Order 14169, issued on January 20, 2025, which directed a 90-day "pause" on nearly all U.S. foreign development assistance to assess programmatic efficiency and alignment with U.S. foreign policy. Following the order, the State Department and USAID issued directives and stop-work orders to grantees, including the plaintiffs, whose work on global HIV/AIDS prevention, support for investigative journalism, and aid to torture victims is funded by congressional appropriations under statutes like the Further Consolidated Appropriations Act of 2024. The plaintiffs alleged that this funding freeze caused immediate and irreparable harm, forcing them to lay off staff and halt critical humanitarian programs.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, arguing that the executive order and its implementation exceeded the President's constitutional authority, violated the separation of powers and the Take Care Clause of Article II, and contravened federal statutes including the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), the Impoundment Control Act (ICA), and the Anti-Deficiency Act.

On February 13, 2025, Judge Ali granted a temporary restraining order (TRO), enjoining the defendant agencies from enforcing the funding freeze and stop-work orders issued between January 20 and February 13 (2025 WL 485324). A contentious period followed, with the plaintiffs filing emergency motions to enforce the TRO, alleging continued non-compliance. The dispute escalated to the Supreme Court, which, after a brief administrative stay, denied the government’s application to vacate the district court's enforcement order on March 5, 2025 (*Dep’t of State v. AIDS Vaccine Advoc. Coal.*, 604 U. S. ____ (2025)).

On March 10, 2025, Judge Ali granted a preliminary injunction (2025 WL 752378). The injunction had two primary components: it enjoined the government from giving effect to the initial wave of suspensions and terminations, and it further enjoined the government from "unlawfully impounding congressionally appropriated foreign aid funds," ordering it to "make available for obligation the full amount of funds that Congress appropriated" in the 2024 appropriations act. Following the injunction, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on May 2, 2025, to address the mass termination of thousands of foreign aid awards that occurred after the initial freeze. The government subsequently moved to dismiss the amended complaint.

The government appealed the preliminary injunction. On August 13, 2025, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit issued its opinion. The appellate court vacated the portion of the preliminary injunction that required the government to make all appropriated foreign aid funds available for obligation. The court held that the plaintiffs lacked a cause of action to enforce the Impoundment Control Act and related appropriations statutes. It reasoned that the ICA's enforcement mechanism, which empowers the Comptroller General to sue the executive branch, impliedly precludes lawsuits by private parties under the APA for the same purpose. The case was remanded for further proceedings on the remaining claims.
results.46093:
On February 10, 2025, a coalition of individual refugees, their U.S.-based family members, and three nonprofit refugee resettlement organizations filed a class-action lawsuit against the President of the United States and the Secretaries of State, Homeland Security, and Health and Human Services. The plaintiffs, represented by private counsel and the International Refugee Assistance Project, challenge an executive order and subsequent agency actions that indefinitely suspended the U.S. Refugee Admissions Program (USRAP).

The lawsuit was precipitated by Executive Order 14163, signed on January 20, 2025, which halted all refugee admissions and decisions on refugee applications. Federal agencies immediately began implementing the order, canceling travel for refugees already approved for resettlement. Days later, on January 24, 2025, the State Department issued "Suspension Notices" to its nonprofit resettlement partners, immediately cutting off federal funding for both overseas refugee processing and domestic resettlement services.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the executive order and the agencies' actions violated the Refugee Act, the Administrative Procedure Act (APA), and the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause. The case was assigned to Judge Jamal N. Whitehead in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington.

On February 28, 2025, Judge Whitehead granted a nationwide preliminary injunction, enjoining the government from enforcing key sections of the executive order and from suspending refugee processing and funding. The day after the court's oral ruling, the State Department issued "Termination Notices," permanently terminating the cooperative agreements it had previously suspended. In response, the plaintiffs filed a supplemental complaint, and on March 24, 2025, the court issued a second preliminary injunction ordering the government to reinstate the terminated agreements.

The government appealed the first preliminary injunction and sought a stay. On March 25, 2025, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit partially stayed the injunction, allowing it to remain in effect only for individuals who were conditionally approved for refugee status before January 20, 2025. Following disputes over the scope of this carve-out, the Ninth Circuit issued two clarification orders on April 21 and May 9, 2025. These orders progressively narrowed the injunction's protection to only those refugees who, in addition to having been approved for status, had also been cleared for travel, had "arranged and confirmable travel plans" before January 20, 2025, and could demonstrate a "strong reliance interest... comparable to Plaintiff Pacito" on a case-by-case basis.

Disputes over compliance with the narrowed injunction continued in the district court. On July 14, 2025, Judge Whitehead issued a Compliance Framework Order establishing a detailed process for identifying and processing potentially protected refugees. The order appointed U.S. Magistrate Judge Michelle L. Peterson to assist with the case-by-case reliance interest assessments. On July 30, 2025, Judge Whitehead granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification and denied the government's motion to dismiss the case.
results.46065:
On February 7, 2025, the States of Washington, Minnesota, and Oregon, joined by three individual physicians, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington against the President of the United States and multiple federal agencies and their secretaries. The suit challenged Executive Order 14,187, which directs federal agencies to terminate research and education grants to medical institutions that provide gender-affirming care to individuals under 19 and directs the Department of Justice to prioritize criminal enforcement against providers of such care. The plaintiffs, represented by their state Attorneys General, argued that the executive order is an act of discrimination and an unconstitutional overreach.

The complaint sought declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging that the order violates the Fifth Amendment's Equal Protection guarantee, the separation of powers doctrine by usurping Congress's spending authority, and the Tenth Amendment by intruding on the states' power to regulate medicine. On February 19, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, adding the State of Colorado as a plaintiff and expanding the lawsuit to challenge a second executive order, E.O. 14,168, which restricts federal funding for any program deemed to "promote gender ideology." The amended complaint also added a cause of action, alleging the orders are unconstitutionally vague in violation of the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause.

The case was assigned to Judge Lauren King. On February 7, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO). On February 14, 2025, Judge King granted the TRO, which was effective for 14 days. The order enjoined the federal government from implementing the funding restrictions in E.O. 14,187 and from enforcing the criminal statute referenced in the order to target gender-affirming care providers in the plaintiff states.

Following the TRO, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. On February 28, 2025, the court granted the motion in part and denied it in part. The preliminary injunction, which remains in effect pending further orders, prohibits the defendants from enforcing the funding restrictions in both E.O. 14,187 and E.O. 14,168 within the four plaintiff states. However, the court denied the request to enjoin the criminal enforcement directive in E.O. 14,187, finding the plaintiffs had not demonstrated a credible threat of prosecution and therefore lacked standing on that specific issue.

A dispute over compliance arose shortly thereafter. On March 6, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for contempt, alleging that the National Institutes of Health (NIH), a subagency of a defendant department, had violated the court's injunctions by terminating a research grant to Seattle Children's Hospital for a study related to gender-affirming care. On March 17, 2025, the court denied the contempt motion, finding the plaintiffs had not yet met the high "clear and convincing evidence" standard for contempt. However, the court granted the plaintiffs' alternative request for expedited discovery into the grant termination and issued an order clarifying the broad scope of "gender-affirming care" protected by its injunction. On March 28, 2025, the defendants notified the court that the NIH had reinstated the grant in full.

On March 21, 2025, the defendants filed a notice of appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, challenging the preliminary injunction and the order granting expedited discovery. Subsequently, on April 23, 2025, Judge King granted the defendants' motion to stay further proceedings in the district court pending the outcome of the appeal. The stay is limited, allowing the parties to address any issues related to the enforcement of the existing preliminary injunction.
results.46028:
On February 4, 2025, two national advocacy organizations (one for LGBTQ+ people and their families, another for LGBTQ+ health professionals), along with several transgender individuals under age 19 and their parents, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland. The suit was brought against the President of the United States, the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), the National Institutes of Health (NIH), the Health Resources and Services Administration (HRSA), the National Science Foundation (NSF), and the heads of those agencies. The plaintiffs are represented by private law firms and legal advocacy groups, including the ACLU and Lambda Legal.

The lawsuit challenges two Executive Orders issued in January 2025. The first, the "Gender Identity Order," declared gender identity a "false idea" and prohibited the use of federal funds to "promote gender ideology." The second, the "Denial of Care Order," directed federal agencies to ensure that institutions receiving federal research or education grants stop providing gender-affirming medical care—which the order termed "chemical and surgical mutilation"—to individuals under age 19. Following the issuance of these orders, hospitals across the country that receive federal funding began canceling appointments and halting this medical care for their patients under 19, including for the individual plaintiffs. Additionally, federal agencies like HRSA and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) issued notices to grant recipients instructing them to terminate programs conflicting with the orders; the government later clarified that the CDC had terminated 17 grants on January 31, 2025, and reinstated them on February 11, 2025.

The plaintiffs allege that the Executive Orders exceed the President's constitutional authority and violate the separation of powers by unilaterally imposing new conditions on funds appropriated by Congress. They also claim the orders violate the Fifth Amendment's Equal Protection and Due Process guarantees by discriminating on the basis of sex and transgender status and infringing on parental rights. Finally, they argue the orders conflict with federal anti-discrimination laws, including Section 1557 of the Affordable Care Act. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to block the enforcement of the orders' funding restrictions.

The case was assigned to Judge Brendan Abell Hurson. On February 5, 2025, the plaintiffs filed an emergency motion for a Temporary Restraining Order (TRO). After a hearing, the court granted the TRO on February 13, 2025, finding the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on their claims.

Following the TRO, the plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction. On March 4, 2025, Judge Hurson granted the motion, issuing a nationwide preliminary injunction that remains in effect pending further court orders. The injunction prohibits the defendant agencies from "conditioning, withholding, or terminating federal funding" based on a healthcare entity providing gender-affirming medical care to a patient under 19. A subsequent emergency motion by the plaintiffs to enforce the injunction, based on new agency notices they argued violated the order, was denied without prejudice on March 28, 2025. The court found the notices did not represent a clear violation of the injunction's command at that time.

On March 21, 2025, the federal government appealed the preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit. On April 9, 2025, the district court granted a joint motion to stay further proceedings in the district court case pending the outcome of the appeal. The Fourth Circuit has since placed the appeal in abeyance, pending a decision by the U.S. Supreme Court in a related case, *U.S. v. Skrmetti*.
results.46306:
On March 26, 2025, a coalition of eleven non-profit legal services organizations filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services (HHS), its Office of Refugee Resettlement (ORR), and the Department of the Interior (DOI). The lawsuit challenges the government's abrupt termination of funding for the legal representation of unaccompanied immigrant children. The plaintiffs, represented by non-profit legal centers, allege that the government's "Cancellation Order," issued on March 21, 2025, violates the Administrative Procedure Act (APA).

The complaint asserts that the funding termination is contrary to law because it contravenes the William Wilberforce Trafficking Victims Protection Reauthorization Act of 2008 (TVPRA), which mandates that the government "shall ensure, to the greatest extent practicable," that unaccompanied children have legal counsel. The action is also alleged to violate the government's own 2024 "Foundational Rule," which requires ORR to fund direct legal representation when appropriations are available. Plaintiffs state that Congress appropriated over $5 billion for these services for fiscal year 2024, with funding available through September 30, 2027. The lawsuit seeks declaratory and injunctive relief to compel the government to resume funding.

The case was assigned to Judge Araceli Martínez-Olguín in the U.S. District Court for the Northern District of California. On March 27, 2025, the plaintiffs moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO) and preliminary injunction. On April 1, 2025, Judge Martínez-Olguín granted a TRO enjoining the government from withdrawing funds for direct legal representation. The TRO was later extended until April 30, 2025.

The government pursued multiple avenues to challenge the TRO. It filed a motion to dissolve the order, which the district court denied. On April 9, 2025, the government filed a motion to recuse Judge Martínez-Olguín, citing her prior employment with one of the plaintiff organizations; the court denied this motion on April 17, 2025. The government also appealed the TRO to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and sought an emergency stay. On April 18, 2025, the Ninth Circuit dismissed the appeal, ruling the TRO was not an appealable order, and a subsequent petition for rehearing en banc was denied.

On April 29, 2025, Judge Martínez-Olguín granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction. The nationwide injunction orders the government to continue funding the legal representation services until a final judgment is issued. The government immediately appealed this preliminary injunction to the Ninth Circuit and again filed an emergency motion for a stay pending appeal. On May 14, 2025, in a published order, a Ninth Circuit panel denied the emergency stay, with one judge dissenting.

Back in the district court, the government filed a motion to dismiss the case, which was denied on July 17, 2025. The government filed its answer to the complaint on July 31, 2025, and submitted the administrative record on August 18, 2025.
results.46201:
On March 6, 2025, eight states, represented by their Attorneys General, filed a lawsuit against the U.S. Department of Education and its leadership. The suit challenges the Department's abrupt termination in February 2025 of approximately $600 million in previously awarded federal grants under the Teacher Quality Partnership (TQP) and Supporting Effective Educator Development (SEED) programs. These congressionally authorized programs were designed to address nationwide teacher shortages. The states allege the terminations, executed via boilerplate letters citing new, undefined "Department priorities" related to Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion (DEI), were unlawful.

The complaint sought declaratory and injunctive relief, asserting that the agency's action was arbitrary, capricious, and not in accordance with law, in violation of the Administrative Procedure Act (APA). On the same day, the states moved for a temporary restraining order (TRO).

On March 10, 2025, Judge Myong J. Joun granted the TRO, finding the states were likely to succeed on the merits because the Department failed to provide a reasoned, individualized explanation for its decision. The TRO, effective for 14 days and later extended, ordered the Department to restore the grant funding.

The Department immediately appealed the TRO to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the First Circuit and filed an emergency motion to stay the order, arguing that the district court lacked subject-matter jurisdiction because the states' claims were essentially contractual and belonged in the Court of Federal Claims under the Tucker Act. On March 21, 2025, the First Circuit denied the stay, finding the Department was unlikely to succeed on the merits of its appeal.

The Department then applied for an emergency stay from the U.S. Supreme Court. On April 4, 2025, the Supreme Court granted the stay, halting the district court's TRO. In a per curiam opinion, the Court reasoned that the government was likely to succeed on its jurisdictional argument, characterizing the relief sought as the enforcement of a "contractual obligation to pay money" that belongs in the Court of Federal Claims. (Reported as *Dep't of Educ. v. California*, 604 U.S. ___ (2025)).

Following the Supreme Court's ruling, the states withdrew their motion for a preliminary injunction on April 8, 2025, and the government voluntarily dismissed its appeal in the First Circuit. On June 2, 2025, the states filed a First Amended Complaint, adding claims that the Department's actions also violated the U.S. Constitution's Spending Clause and the separation of powers doctrine. The case was subsequently reassigned to Judge Angel Kelley. The Department has filed a motion to dismiss the amended complaint for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction or, in the alternative, to transfer the case to the Court of Federal Claims.
results.45984:
On January 28, 2025, a group of current and prospective transgender service members, represented by legal advocacy organizations including GLBTQ Legal Advocates & Defenders and the National Center for Lesbian Rights, filed a lawsuit against the United States government, the President, the Secretary of Defense, and the military departments. The number of individual plaintiffs grew from eight to 32 through several amended complaints. The lawsuit challenges a January 27, 2025, executive order and its subsequent implementing policies, which effectively ban transgender individuals from enlisting or continuing to serve in the U.S. Armed Forces.

The factual basis of the case stems from a reversal of military policy. A 2021 policy had permitted transgender individuals to serve openly if they met military standards. The 2025 executive order revoked that policy, stating that transgender status is incompatible with military readiness, cohesion, honesty, and integrity. The plaintiffs allege this ban is not based on evidence but on unconstitutional animus, violating the Equal Protection and Due Process components of the Fifth Amendment to the U.S. Constitution. They seek declaratory judgments that the ban is unconstitutional and preliminary and permanent injunctions to prohibit its enforcement.

The case was assigned to Judge Ana C. Reyes of the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia. The plaintiffs filed for a preliminary injunction on February 3, 2025, and a temporary restraining order the following day. After expedited briefing and hearings, Judge Reyes issued a detailed memorandum opinion and order on March 18, 2025, granting a nationwide preliminary injunction (2025 WL 842332). The court found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits, reasoning that the ban was likely motivated by unconstitutional animus rather than legitimate military concerns, noting the policy's derogatory language and lack of supporting evidence. The injunction restored the pre-existing policy, prohibiting the defendants from separating or denying accession to service members based on their transgender status and from denying them medically necessary care.

The government moved to dissolve the injunction on March 21, 2025, arguing that new guidance clarified the policy was based on the medical condition of gender dysphoria, not transgender status itself. On March 26, 2025, Judge Reyes denied the motion, finding the new guidance did not change the policy's discriminatory nature (2025 WL 914716).

The government filed a notice of appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the D.C. Circuit on March 26, 2025. The next day, it filed an emergency motion for an administrative stay and a stay of the injunction pending the appeal's outcome. On March 27, 2025, the D.C. Circuit granted an administrative stay to give the court time to consider the motion for a stay pending appeal, temporarily pausing the district court's injunction.
results.45964:
On January 21, 2025, the states of Washington, Arizona, Illinois, and Oregon filed a lawsuit against the President of the United States and several federal agencies in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. The suit challenged a January 20, 2025 Executive Order, "Protecting the Meaning and Value of American Citizenship," which declared that children born in the United States would not be recognized as citizens if their mother was unlawfully present or in a lawful but temporary status, and their father was not a U.S. citizen or lawful permanent resident. The states alleged the order violated the Fourteenth Amendment’s Citizenship Clause and the Immigration and Nationality Act (8 U.S.C. § 1401) and would cause them irreparable harm through the loss of federal funding for programs like Medicaid and CHIP and by imposing significant administrative burdens. They sought a declaratory judgment that the order was unlawful and an injunction to block its enforcement. The states' counsel were their respective Attorneys General.

The case was assigned to Judge John C. Coughenour. Shortly after filing, a separate class-action lawsuit was filed by several pregnant noncitizen women, represented by the Northwest Immigrant Rights Project, seeking similar relief. On January 27, 2025, Judge Coughenour consolidated the two cases.

On January 23, 2025, the court granted the states a nationwide temporary restraining order (TRO) against the Executive Order. Following expedited briefing, on February 6, 2025, the court granted a nationwide preliminary injunction. The court found the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits, reasoning the order was contrary to the plain text of the Fourteenth Amendment and the Supreme Court's precedent in *United States v. Wong Kim Ark*. It held that the states had standing due to direct economic and administrative harms and that a nationwide injunction was necessary to provide them complete relief due to the likelihood of interstate travel.

The federal government appealed the preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit and sought an emergency partial stay to limit the injunction's scope. On February 19, 2025, a Ninth Circuit panel denied the stay. The government then applied to the U.S. Supreme Court for a partial stay, which was consolidated with similar applications from related cases, *Trump v. CASA, Inc.* and *Trump v. State of New Jersey*. On June 27, 2025, the Supreme Court granted the government's application, holding that universal injunctions likely exceed the equitable authority of federal courts. The Court stayed the injunction to the extent it was broader than necessary to provide complete relief to the specific plaintiffs, but it did not rule on the underlying constitutionality of the Executive Order.

On July 23, 2025, the Ninth Circuit issued its opinion on the merits of the preliminary injunction appeal (*State of Washington v. Trump*, No. 25-807). The panel affirmed the district court's order. It held that the states had standing based on direct financial injuries. It dismissed the individual plaintiffs' claims, noting they were covered by a recently certified nationwide class action in a related case in the District of New Hampshire (*"Barbara," et al. v. Trump*). The panel agreed with the district court that the Executive Order was likely unconstitutional. Despite the Supreme Court's stay order, the panel concluded that a universal injunction remained necessary to afford the states complete relief from the administrative and financial harms they would suffer due to interstate mobility. Judge Bumatay dissented in part, arguing the states lacked standing.
results.VR-LA-0120:
On May 19, 2020, a group of individual Louisiana voters and two non-profit organizations, the League of Women Voters of Louisiana and the Crescent City Media Group, filed a lawsuit against the Louisiana Governor, Secretary of State, Attorney General, and two parish Registrars of Voters. The plaintiffs were represented by private counsel and attorneys from the Southern Poverty Law Center and the Fair Elections Center. The case was consolidated with a similar case, *Power Coalition for Equity and Justice v. Edwards*, No. 3:20-cv-00283, with this case designated as the lead.

The lawsuit was a response to the COVID-19 pandemic and its impact on the safety of the 2020 elections. The plaintiffs argued that several provisions of Louisiana's election laws forced voters to choose between exercising their fundamental right to vote and risking their health. The challenged provisions included: (1) the "Excuse Requirement," which limits eligibility for absentee mail-in voting to specific categories of voters; (2) the "Witness Requirement," which mandates a witness signature on an absentee ballot; and (3) the "Cure Prohibition," an alleged failure to provide voters with notice and an opportunity to fix errors on their absentee ballots.

The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief, bringing their claims under 42 U.S.C. § 1983 for violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments to the U.S. Constitution (undue burden on the right to vote, unconstitutional condition on the right to bodily integrity, and procedural due process) and Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act. They alleged the challenged provisions disproportionately burdened Black voters, who have been more severely affected by the COVID-19 pandemic.

The plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction to block enforcement of the challenged provisions for all 2020 elections. In response, the State of Louisiana, through the Attorney General, successfully moved to intervene as a defendant. The Attorney General and the parish Registrars of Voters then filed motions to dismiss the case, arguing the court lacked jurisdiction due to the plaintiffs' lack of standing and the presence of a non-justiciable political question. Following these motions, the plaintiffs filed amended complaints that removed the parish registrars as defendants.

On June 22, 2020, Judge Shelly D. Dick granted the defendants' motions to dismiss, finding the plaintiffs lacked standing because their alleged injuries were speculative and not "certainly impending." The court initially dismissed the case with prejudice. However, after the plaintiffs filed a motion to amend, the court issued an amended judgment on June 30, 2020, dismissing the case without prejudice on the grounds that a dismissal for lack of jurisdiction is not a ruling on the merits.
results.46057:
On February 6, 2025, a group of eight active-duty transgender service members, one aspiring transgender service member, and a civil rights organization, Gender Justice League, filed a lawsuit in the U.S. District Court for the Western District of Washington. Represented by private counsel and legal services organizations including Lambda Legal and the Human Rights Campaign Foundation, the plaintiffs challenged the constitutionality of Executive Order 14183, the "2025 Military Ban," issued by the President on January 27, 2025. The ban and its related directives categorically prohibit transgender individuals from serving in the armed forces, asserting that being transgender is incompatible with military service. The plaintiffs, many of whom have long and decorated military careers, argued this policy was discriminatory and lacked any rational basis.

The lawsuit was filed against the President, the United States, the Department of Defense (DoD), and the military service branches and their secretaries. The plaintiffs alleged that the ban violated the equal protection and due process guarantees of the Fifth Amendment and the free speech protections of the First Amendment. They also brought a claim for equitable estoppel, arguing they had detrimentally relied on previous policies that allowed open service. The plaintiffs sought a declaratory judgment that the ban is unconstitutional and an injunction to prevent its implementation and enforcement.

The case was assigned to Judge Benjamin H. Settle. On February 19, 2025, the plaintiffs filed a motion for a preliminary injunction to halt the ban's enforcement, arguing they and thousands of other service members faced imminent and irreparable harm, including the loss of their careers, benefits, and healthcare. After the DoD issued guidance on February 26, 2025, detailing a plan to begin separating transgender service members by March 28, 2025, the plaintiffs filed supplemental briefs highlighting the urgency of their motion.

On March 27, 2025, Judge Settle granted a nationwide preliminary injunction. In his memorandum opinion, the judge found that the plaintiffs were likely to succeed on the merits of their claims, concluding that the ban was not the product of reasoned military judgment and appeared to be based on animus. The opinion stated that the government provided no evidence that open service by transgender individuals under the previous policy had harmed military readiness or unit cohesion. The court's order restored the prior policy, which permitted transgender individuals to serve openly. The case was noted as being related to similar challenges, including *Talbott v. United States*, 2025 WL 842332 (D.D.C. Mar. 18, 2025).

The government filed an immediate notice of appeal to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit on March 28, 2025, and sought an emergency stay of the injunction. On March 31, 2025, the Ninth Circuit denied the request for an administrative stay. On April 18, 2025, it denied the motion for a stay pending appeal, finding the government had not demonstrated it would suffer irreparable harm.

Following the Ninth Circuit's denial, the government applied to the U.S. Supreme Court for a stay. On May 6, 2025, the Supreme Court granted the application, staying the district court's nationwide injunction pending the disposition of the appeal in the Ninth Circuit and any subsequent petition for a writ of certiorari. The government filed its answer to the plaintiffs' amended complaint on May 19, 2025.
results.45965:
On January 21, 2025, two immigrant-rights organizations and five pregnant noncitizen mothers filed a lawsuit against the President of the United States, the heads of several federal agencies, and the United States. The suit challenges a January 20, 2025, Executive Order titled “Protecting the Meaning and Value of American Citizenship,” which purports to deny birthright citizenship to children born in the U.S. to mothers with unlawful or temporary immigration status whose fathers are not citizens or lawful permanent residents.

The plaintiffs, represented by legal services organizations and the Institute for Constitutional Advocacy and Protection at Georgetown University, alleged that the Executive Order was an unconstitutional ultra vires action that violated the Citizenship Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment and its statutory codification in 8 U.S.C. § 1401(a). They sought declaratory and injunctive relief to prohibit the federal government from implementing the order, arguing it would deny their children guaranteed citizenship, render them stateless, and cut off access to essential benefits.

The case was assigned to Judge Deborah L. Boardman in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland. On February 5, 2025, Judge Boardman granted the plaintiffs' motion for a preliminary injunction, finding they had shown an extremely strong likelihood of success on the merits. The order enjoined the implementation and enforcement of the Executive Order nationwide.

The federal government appealed the preliminary injunction to the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit and moved to stay the injunction's nationwide scope pending appeal. The district court denied the stay on February 18, 2025, and the Fourth Circuit also denied a stay on February 28, 2025.

The government then filed an emergency application with the U.S. Supreme Court for a partial stay. On June 27, 2025, the Supreme Court issued a landmark opinion in *Trump v. CASA, Inc.*, holding that universal injunctions likely exceed the equitable authority granted to federal courts by the Judiciary Act of 1789. The Court partially stayed the injunction to the extent it was broader than necessary to provide complete relief to the named plaintiffs but noted that class actions under Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 23 remained a viable path for broader relief. The Court also stayed the injunction's prohibition on federal agencies developing implementation guidance.

Following the Supreme Court's decision, the plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint on June 27, 2025, adding new plaintiffs and class-action allegations. On July 29, 2025, the Fourth Circuit dismissed the government's appeal and remanded the case to the district court. On August 7, 2025, Judge Boardman granted the plaintiffs' motion for class certification, certifying a nationwide class of all children born in the U.S. on or after February 19, 2025, who are affected by the Executive Order. On the same day, the court granted a new, classwide preliminary injunction, enjoining the federal government from enforcing the Executive Order against all members of the certified class. The court also dissolved its original February 5 injunction. The litigation is related to similar challenges filed against the same Executive Order in other federal districts, including *Washington v. Trump* and *New Jersey v. Trump*.
results.VR-SC-0078:
On April 22, 2020, several South Carolina voters and a non-profit organization, The Family Unit, Inc., filed a lawsuit against South Carolina's Governor and state election officials. The plaintiffs, represented by the ACLU and the NAACP Legal Defense & Educational Fund, Inc., challenged two state election laws amid the COVID-19 pandemic. The first, the "Excuse Requirement," limited absentee voting to those who met one of 15 statutory criteria. The second, the "Witness Requirement," mandated that a voter's signature on a mail-in absentee ballot envelope be witnessed by another person. The plaintiffs argued that these laws unconstitutionally forced voters, particularly the elderly, those with pre-existing medical conditions, and African Americans disproportionately affected by the virus, to choose between their health and their fundamental right to vote. The lawsuit sought declaratory and injunctive relief, alleging violations of the First and Fourteenth Amendments and the Voting Rights Act (VRA).

The plaintiffs moved for a preliminary injunction on April 28, 2020. The South Carolina Republican Party (SCGOP) was granted permission to intervene in the case to defend the state's election laws. Before the court ruled on the injunction, the South Carolina General Assembly passed a temporary law permitting no-excuse absentee voting for the June 9, 2020 primary and any subsequent runoffs, which mooted the plaintiffs' immediate challenge to the Excuse Requirement.

On May 25, 2020, Judge J. Michelle Childs granted in part the motion for a preliminary injunction. The court enjoined the state from enforcing the Witness Requirement for the June 2020 primaries and runoffs and ordered officials to publicly inform voters of the change. The court found that in the context of the pandemic, the Witness Requirement placed a substantial burden on voters that outweighed the state's asserted interest in preventing fraud, especially since the State Election Commission's director had stated the requirement offered "no benefit to election officials."

Following the primary, the plaintiffs filed a First Amended Complaint on July 13, 2020, adding the South Carolina State Conference of the NAACP as a plaintiff and asserting additional claims under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). The Speaker of the South Carolina House of Representatives and the President of the South Carolina Senate were also permitted to intervene as defendants. The State Election Commission and the SCGOP filed motions for summary judgment on August 10, 2020.

On September 15, 2020, the South Carolina General Assembly again acted, passing legislation that suspended the Excuse Requirement for the November 2020 general election. Three days later, in a separate but related case, *Middleton v. Andino*, Judge Childs enjoined the Witness Requirement for the November 2020 election. Citing these developments, which effectively granted the plaintiffs the relief they sought for the 2020 election cycle, Judge Childs issued an order on September 18, 2020, that sua sponte stayed the *Thomas* case, holding all pending motions in abeyance and cancelling the trial scheduled to begin on September 22, 2020. The stay remains in effect until the plaintiffs request it be lifted.
results.JC-MD-0017:
On April 21, 2020, a group of current and former detainees at the Prince George’s County Jail filed a class action lawsuit against the Director of the Prince George’s County Department of Corrections. The detainees, represented by Civil Rights Corps and WilmerHale, alleged that the jail's response to the COVID-19 pandemic created an unconstitutional risk of serious harm.

The factual basis for the case was an uncontrolled outbreak of COVID-19 within the facility. The detainees alleged that the jail failed to implement basic public health measures recommended by the CDC, such as providing free and adequate access to soap and cleaning supplies, enforcing social distancing, and properly sanitizing common areas. They further claimed that medical care was grossly substandard, with symptomatic individuals being denied treatment or returned to the general population, and that those who tested positive were held in filthy, unsanitary isolation cells with minimal monitoring. The complaint also challenged the jail's use of a facility-wide, 23-hour-a-day lockdown and a policy of refusing to release COVID-positive individuals even after they were legally entitled to do so.

The lawsuit was brought under 42 U.S.C. § 1983, alleging violations of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments. A "Medically Vulnerable Subclass" of pretrial detainees with preexisting health conditions also petitioned for writs of habeas corpus under 28 U.S.C. § 2241, seeking immediate release. The plaintiffs sought declaratory and injunctive relief to compel the jail to comply with constitutional and public health standards.

Filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Maryland, the case was assigned to Judge Paula Xinis. Concurrent with their complaint, the detainees filed an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO). In response, on May 1, 2020, the court appointed Dr. Carlos Franco-Paredes as an independent medical expert to inspect the jail. Dr. Franco-Paredes's subsequent report concluded that a "large outbreak" had occurred, fueled by significant undertesting, inadequately trained medical staff, and a lack of any specific plan to protect high-risk detainees.

On May 21, 2020, Judge Xinis issued a Memorandum Opinion and a TRO, granting partial relief to the detainees. The court found that the jail's "undertesting, . . . inadequate treatment and isolation of COVID-19 symptomatic detainees, and . . . no plan for those at high risk" demonstrated a likelihood of success on the merits of their constitutional claims. The TRO ordered the jail director to develop and file comprehensive written plans within five days for identifying and protecting high-risk detainees, improving staff training and medical response, and establishing clear criteria for COVID-19 testing and isolation. The director also had to submit follow-up reports on testing and sanitation measures.

The Director of the Department of Corrections appealed the TRO to the Fourth Circuit and moved to stay the order, which Judge Xinis denied on June 3, 2020. The Fourth Circuit also denied a stay and later dismissed the appeal.

On July 7, 2020, the detainees filed a First Amended Complaint, adding new claims that the jail's ongoing, indefinite lockdown subjected them to unconstitutional solitary confinement in violation of the Eighth and Fourteenth Amendments. On July 17, 2020, the Director filed a motion to dismiss the amended complaint, arguing the claims were moot for released plaintiffs, that the remaining plaintiffs had failed to exhaust administrative remedies under the Prison Litigation Reform Act (PLRA), and that the complaint failed to state a claim. That motion remains pending. The docket indicates that the case was referred to a Magistrate Judge for settlement conferences, and on September 18, 2020, the court stayed all deadlines pending the outcome of those discussions.
results.IM-FL-0029:
On April 13, 2020, a group of civil immigration detainees filed a class-action lawsuit against the U.S. government, including the Miami Field Office Director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE) and the U.S. Attorney General. The detainees, held at Krome Service Processing Center, Broward Transitional Center, and Glades County Detention Center in South Florida, alleged that the conditions of their confinement during the COVID-19 pandemic placed them at imminent risk of serious illness or death. Represented by a coalition of private, legal services, and non-profit counsel including the University of Miami School of Law Immigration Clinic and the Southern Poverty Law Center, they argued that crowded dormitory-style housing, inadequate sanitation, and insufficient hygiene supplies made it impossible to comply with CDC guidelines for social distancing and preventing viral transmission.

The lawsuit was filed as a petition for a writ of habeas corpus and a complaint for declaratory and injunctive relief. The detainees alleged violations of their rights to reasonable safety under the Fifth Amendment's Due Process Clause and violations of federal administrative law under the Accardi Doctrine, which requires agencies to follow their own regulations. They sought immediate release from custody and a court order compelling the detention centers to comply with CDC public health protocols.

The case was assigned to Judge Marcia G. Cooke. Following an emergency motion for a temporary restraining order (TRO), Magistrate Judge Jonathan Goodman issued a Report and Recommendation. On April 30, 2020, Judge Cooke adopted the report in part, issuing a TRO that directed ICE to evaluate detainees for release, reduce facility populations toward a goal of 75% capacity, provide masks and cleaning supplies, and submit regular compliance reports to the court.

On June 6, 2020, the court issued an omnibus order that granted a preliminary injunction, extending and expanding the requirements of the TRO. The order also certified a class of all civil immigration detainees held at the three facilities from the date the action was filed into the future. Throughout the proceedings, the detainees filed motions to compel compliance, alleging that ICE continued to violate the court's orders, particularly regarding the improper cohorting of COVID-19 positive individuals with uninfected detainees, inconsistent provision of masks and soap, and conducting transfers without adequate safety precautions.

Due to these ongoing disputes over compliance, the court appointed Matthew C. Dates as a Special Master on July 17, 2020, to inspect the facilities and report on conditions. In his September 1, 2020 report, the Special Master found that while the facilities were generally clean and had supplies, social distancing remained insufficient due to the facilities' physical layouts and population levels. After the government filed a motion for summary judgment, the parties entered into a court-enforced settlement agreement on June 28, 2021, resolving all class-wide claims.

The settlement's significant terms require the detention facilities to:
*   Comply with all applicable ICE and CDC guidelines.
*   Implement a COVID-19 vaccination protocol, making vaccines available at no cost to all detainees.
*   Maintain population density at or below 75% of capacity in each living area.
*   Test all detainees who exhibit symptoms of or have had close contact with COVID-19.
*   Properly isolate and quarantine detainees who test positive or have been exposed, prohibiting the housing of COVID-19 positive individuals with those who have not tested positive.
*   Provide unrestricted access to soap and hand sanitizer and issue new masks three times per week.
*   Adhere to strict testing and safety protocols before transferring any detainee.

The court retains jurisdiction to enforce the agreement, which is set to remain in effect for six months or until every detainee has been offered a full vaccination course, whichever is later. The agreement is connected to other related cases, including *Fraihat v. ICE*.
